AI.motivation: To address the need for scalable and fair evaluation of autobidding algorithms in advertisement auctions, which are central to e-commerce revenue generation.
AI.method: The authors utilize a recent open-source bidding environment and benchmark classical and RL-based autobidding algorithms using multiple performance-oriented metrics.
AI.result: The study identifies promising use cases, potential drawbacks of autobidding algorithms, and evaluates them in terms of efficiency, costs, and budget pacing.
AI.conclusion: The proposed evaluation protocol aids e-commerce practitioners in assessing autobidding algorithms based on diverse metrics relevant to company goals.

title: AMAuT: A Flexible and Efficient Multiview Audio Transformer Framework Trained from Scratch
summary:
Recent foundational models, SSAST, EAT, HuBERT, Qwen-Audio, and Audio
Flamingo, achieve top-tier results across standard audio benchmarks but are
limited by fixed input rates and durations, hindering their reusability. This
paper introduces the Augmentation-driven Multiview Audio Transformer (AMAuT), a
training-from-scratch framework that eliminates the dependency on pre-trained
weights while supporting arbitrary sample rates and audio lengths. AMAuT
integrates four key components: (1) augmentation-driven multiview learning for
robustness, (2) a conv1 + conv7 + conv1 one-dimensional CNN bottleneck for
stable temporal encoding, (3) dual CLS + TAL tokens for bidirectional context
representation, and (4) test-time adaptation/augmentation (TTA^2) to improve
inference reliability. Experiments on five public benchmarks, AudioMNIST,
SpeechCommands V1 & V2, VocalSound, and CochlScene, show that AMAuT achieves
accuracies up to 99.8% while consuming less than 3% of the GPU hours required
by comparable pre-trained models. Thus, AMAuT presents a highly efficient and
flexible alternative to large pre-trained models, making state-of-the-art audio
classification accessible in computationally constrained settings.

AI.tldr: The Augmentation-driven Multiview Audio Transformer (AMAuT) achieves high audio classification accuracy without relying on pre-trained weights, offering flexibility in input configurations while requiring minimal computational resources.
AI.motivation: Current foundational audio models are limited by their dependence on pre-trained weights and fixed input configurations, reducing flexibility and computational efficiency.
AI.method: AMAuT introduces a novel training-from-scratch framework with multiview learning, a CNN bottleneck for temporal encoding, bidirectional context tokens, and test-time adaptation/augmentation to ensure robustness and efficiency.
AI.result: AMAuT achieves up to 99.8% accuracy on benchmarks, using less than 3% of the GPU hours required by comparable models.
AI.conclusion: AMAuT demonstrates an efficient, flexible, and high-performing alternative to large pre-trained models, ideal for resource-constrained audio classification applications.

title: Directive, Metacognitive or a Blend of Both? A Comparison of AI-Generated Feedback Types on Student Engagement, Confidence, and Outcomes
summary:
Feedback is one of the most powerful influences on student learning, with
extensive research examining how best to implement it in educational settings.
Increasingly, feedback is being generated by artificial intelligence (AI),
offering scalable and adaptive responses. Two widely studied approaches are
directive feedback, which gives explicit explanations and reduces cognitive
load to speed up learning, and metacognitive feedback which prompts learners to
reflect, track their progress, and develop self-regulated learning (SRL)
skills. While both approaches have clear theoretical advantages, their
comparative effects on engagement, confidence, and quality of work remain
underexplored. This study presents a semester-long randomised controlled trial
with 329 students in an introductory design and programming course using an
adaptive educational platform. Participants were assigned to receive directive,
metacognitive, or hybrid AI-generated feedback that blended elements of both
directive and metacognitive feedback. Results showed that revision behaviour
differed across feedback conditions, with Hybrid prompting the most revisions
compared to Directive and Metacognitive. Confidence ratings were uniformly
high, and resource quality outcomes were comparable across conditions. These
findings highlight the promise of AI in delivering feedback that balances
clarity with reflection. Hybrid approaches, in particular, show potential to
combine actionable guidance for immediate improvement with opportunities for
self-reflection and metacognitive growth.

AI.tldr: This study examines the impact of three types of AI-generated feedback (Directive, Metacognitive, Hybrid) in a semester-long trial involving 329 students and finds Hybrid feedback most effective in triggering revision behavior.
AI.motivation: The paper explores the potential of AI-generated feedback in education and seeks to compare the impact of directive, metacognitive, and hybrid feedback on student engagement, confidence, and work quality.
AI.method: The study uses a semester-long randomized controlled trial with 329 students in an introductory course, assigning them to groups receiving either directive, metacognitive, or hybrid AI-generated feedback.
AI.result: Results showed that Hybrid feedback prompted the most revisions among students while confidence ratings remained high and work quality comparable across groups.
AI.conclusion: Hybrid AI-generated feedback is promising as it combines actionable guidance for improvement with self-reflection opportunities, supporting both immediate learning and metacognitive skill development.

title: On Controlled Change: Generative AI's Impact on Professional Authority in Journalism
summary:
Using (generative) artificial intelligence tools and systems in journalism is
expected to increase journalists' production rates, transform newsrooms'
economic models, and further personalize the audience's news consumption
practices. Since its release in 2022, OpenAI's ChatGPT and other large language
models have raised the alarms inside news organizations, not only for bringing
new challenges to news reporting and fact-checking but also for what these
technologies would mean for journalists' professional authority in journalism.
This paper examines how journalists in Dutch media manage the integration of AI
technologies into their daily routines. Drawing from 13 interviews with
editors, journalists, and innovation managers in different news outlets and
media companies, we propose the concept of controlled change. as a heuristic to
explain how journalists are proactively setting guidelines, experimenting with
AI tools, and identifying their limitations and capabilities. Using
professional authority as a theoretical framework, we argue that journalists
anticipate and integrate AI technologies in a supervised manner and identify
three primary mechanisms through which journalists manage this integration: (1)
developing adaptive guidelines that align AI use with ethical codes, (2)
experimenting with AI technologies to determine their necessity and fit, and
(3) critically assessing the capabilities and limitations of AI systems.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates how Dutch journalists are managing AI integration in their workflows using interviews and proposes the concept of "controlled change" as a framework.
AI.motivation: The paper seeks to explore the challenges and opportunities AI technologies, like ChatGPT, bring to journalism, examining their impact on journalists' authority and newsroom practices.
AI.method: The research utilizes qualitative methods by conducting 13 interviews with editors, journalists, and innovation managers in Dutch media organizations.
AI.result: Journalists are employing three primary mechanisms to manage AI integration: creating adaptive ethical guidelines, experimenting with AI tools, and critically evaluating their capabilities and limitations.
AI.conclusion: Journalists are proactively managing AI integration through supervised practices that preserve their professional authority while adapting to technological changes.

title: Online Two-Stage Submodular Maximization
summary:
Given a collection of monotone submodular functions, the goal of Two-Stage
Submodular Maximization (2SSM) [Balkanski et al., 2016] is to restrict the
ground set so an objective selected u.a.r. from the collection attains a high
maximal value, on average, when optimized over the restricted ground set. We
introduce the Online Two-Stage Submodular Maximization (O2SSM) problem, in
which the submodular objectives are revealed in an online fashion. We study
this problem for weighted threshold potential functions, a large and important
subclass of monotone submodular functions that includes influence maximization,
data summarization, and facility location, to name a few. We design an
algorithm that achieves sublinear $(1 - 1/e)^2$-regret under general matroid
constraints and $(1 - 1/e)(1-e^{-k}k^k/k!)$-regret in the case of uniform
matroids of rank $k$; the latter also yields a state-of-the-art bound for the
(offline) 2SSM problem. We empirically validate the performance of our online
algorithm with experiments on real datasets.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a new problem called Online Two-Stage Submodular Maximization (O2SSM) and proposes a sublinear regret algorithm tailored to weighted threshold potential functions, validated both theoretically and empirically.
AI.motivation: To address limitations in Two-Stage Submodular Maximization (2SSM) for selecting subsets under online-revealed objectives, especially within the context of monotone submodular functions such as influence maximization and facility location.
AI.method: The authors propose an algorithm for O2SSM that guarantees sublinear regret: achieving $(1 - 1/e)^2$-regret under general matroid constraints and a better $(1 - 1/e)(1-e^{-k}k^k/k!)$-regret for uniform matroids of rank $k$.
AI.result: The algorithm achieves state-of-the-art theoretical bounds and shows promising results when tested experimentally using real datasets.
AI.conclusion: The proposed algorithm effectively addresses the O2SSM problem, offers superior theoretical regret bounds, and demonstrates empirical success, contributing significantly to the fields of online optimization and submodular function maximization.

title: Remarks on a recent preprint of Chernikov and Towsner
summary:
In this brief note, we first give a counterexample to a theorem in Chernikov
and Towsner, arXiv:2510.02420(1). In arXiv:2510.02420(2), the theorem has
changed but as we explain the proof has a mistake. The change in the statement,
due to changes in the underlying definition, affects the paper's claims. Since
that theorem had been relevant to connecting the work of their paper to
Coregliano-Malliaris high-arity PAC learning, a connection which now
disappears, we also explain why their definitions miss crucial aspects that our
work was designed to grapple with.

AI.tldr: The paper identifies and reasons about errors in a previous theorem, explaining its implications on related works.
AI.motivation: The authors aim to address errors in a theorem from Chernikov and Towsner, which affects connections to prior PAC learning work.
AI.method: The paper provides counterexamples, analyzes defects in definitions, and explains the incorrect reasoning impacting proofs.
AI.result: It demonstrates flaws in the initial theorem, its revised statement, and clarifies lost connections to high-arity PAC learning.
AI.conclusion: Errors in prior definitions and proofs undermine the earlier claims, and the authors point out missed aspects of their work that were relevant.

title: Bridging Earth and Space: A Survey on HAPS for Non-Terrestrial Networks
comment:
30 pages. This work has been submitted to IEEE Communications Surveys
  & Tutorials (under review)
summary:
HAPS are emerging as key enablers in the evolution of 6G wireless networks,
bridging terrestrial and non-terrestrial infrastructures. Operating in the
stratosphere, HAPS can provide wide-area coverage, low-latency,
energy-efficient broadband communications with flexible deployment options for
diverse applications. This survey delivers a comprehensive overview of HAPS use
cases, technologies, and integration strategies within the 6G ecosystem. The
roles of HAPS in extending connectivity to underserved regions, supporting
dynamic backhauling, enabling massive IoT, and delivering reliable low-latency
communications for autonomous and immersive services are discussed. The paper
reviews state-of-the-art architectures for terrestrial and non-terrestrial
network integration, highlights recent field trials. Furthermore, key enabling
technologies such as channel modeling, AI-driven resource allocation,
interference control, mobility management, and energy-efficient communications
are examined. The paper also outlines open research challenges. By addressing
existing gaps in the literature, this survey positions HAPS as a foundational
component of globally integrated, resilient, and sustainable 6G networks.

AI.tldr: The paper reviews High Altitude Platform Stations (HAPS) and their roles in enabling 6G networks, discussing use cases, technologies, architectures, trials, and challenges.
AI.motivation: HAPS are crucial for bridging terrestrial and non-terrestrial infrastructures, delivering wide-area coverage, energy-efficient communication, low-latency, and extending connectivity for 6G networks.
AI.method: The survey examines HAPS use cases, technologies such as AI-driven resource allocation and interference control, network integration strategies, and reviews recent field trials.
AI.result: The paper identifies HAPS roles in underserved connectivity, dynamic backhauling, massive IoT, and low-latency systems, while showcasing state-of-the-art architectures and enabling technologies.
AI.conclusion: HAPS serve as key foundational components for globally integrated and sustainable 6G networks, addressing connectivity gaps, and advancing research challenges.

title: Exploring the Effect of DNN Depth on Adversarial Attacks in Network Intrusion Detection Systems
summary:
Adversarial attacks pose significant challenges to Machine Learning (ML)
systems and especially Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) by subtly manipulating
inputs to induce incorrect predictions. This paper investigates whether
increasing the layer depth of deep neural networks affects their robustness
against adversarial attacks in the Network Intrusion Detection System (NIDS)
domain. We compare the adversarial robustness of various deep neural networks
across both \ac{NIDS} and computer vision domains (the latter being widely used
in adversarial attack experiments). Our experimental results reveal that in the
NIDS domain, adding more layers does not necessarily improve their performance,
yet it may actually significantly degrade their robustness against adversarial
attacks. Conversely, in the computer vision domain, adding more layers exhibits
a more modest impact on robustness. These findings can guide the development of
robust neural networks for (NIDS) applications and highlight the unique
characteristics of network security domains within the (ML) landscape.

AI.tldr: Increasing the layer depth in Deep Neural Networks does not universally enhance adversarial robustness, especially in Network Intrusion Detection System (NIDS) applications.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to address whether the depth of deep neural networks impacts their robustness against adversarial attacks, specifically within the NIDS domain.
AI.method: The adversarial robustness of DNNs was evaluated by comparing deep neural networks across the NIDS and computer vision domains.
AI.result: In the NIDS domain, adding more layers may degrade robustness against adversarial attacks, whereas in the computer vision domain, deeper layers have a modest impact on robustness.
AI.conclusion: Increasing layer depth does not guarantee improved adversarial robustness in NIDS and may negatively influence it, guiding the design of robust neural networks tailored for specific applications.
